questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A stitch in time saves ___.'
questions.explanation: This proverb means fixing a small problem now prevents it from becoming a bigger problem later.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Prevention is better than ___.'
questions.explanation: It's easier to stop something bad from happening than to repair the damage after it has happened.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'The early bird catches the ___.'
questions.explanation: Those who act quickly or arrive first have the best chance of success.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Birds of a feather flock ___.'
questions.explanation: People with similar interests, tastes, or characteristics tend to associate with each other.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A friend in need is a friend ___.'
questions.explanation: A true friend is one who helps you when you are in trouble.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Make hay while the sun ___.'
questions.explanation: Take advantage of favorable conditions while they last.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A burnt child dreads the ___.'
questions.explanation: Someone who has had a bad experience is very cautious about similar situations.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Still waters run ___.'
questions.explanation: A quiet person may have deep thoughts or hidden talents.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A fool and his money are soon ___.'
questions.explanation: Foolish people spend money carelessly and quickly become poor.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Nothing ventured, nothing ___.'
questions.explanation: You cannot achieve anything without taking risks.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'The proof of the pudding is in the ___.'
questions.explanation: The true value or quality of something can only be judged when it is put to use.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'A new broom sweeps ___.'
questions.explanation: A new person in a job tends to make many changes at first.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Hard work always pays ___.'
questions.explanation: If you work hard, you will eventually be rewarded for your efforts.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'You can take a horse to water, but you can't make it ___.'
questions.explanation: You can give someone an opportunity, but you cannot force them to take it.

questions.question: Complete the proverb: 'Tall oaks from small acorns ___.'
questions.explanation: Great things can have small beginnings.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'let the cat out of the bag' mean?
questions.answer: It means to reveal a secret accidentally or carelessly.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'on cloud nine' mean?
questions.answer: It means to be extremely happy or elated.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'take the bull by the horns' mean?
questions.answer: It means to face a difficult situation directly and with courage.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'face the music' mean?
questions.answer: It means to accept the unpleasant consequences of one's actions.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'hold the fort' mean?
questions.answer: It means to take care of an organization or business when the person in charge is away.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'paddle one's own canoe' mean?
questions.answer: It means to do something without anyone's help or interference; to be independent.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'put the cart before the horse' mean?
questions.answer: It means to do things in the wrong order.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'make a beeline for' mean?
questions.answer: It means to go directly towards something without deviation.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'a dog in the manger' mean?
questions.answer: It means someone who prevents others from having or using what they themselves don't need or use.
key_points: don't need it but won't share

questions.question: What does the idiom 'keep one on their toes' mean?
questions.answer: It means to be always ready to deal with anything that might happen; to stay alert.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'water off a duck's back' mean?
questions.answer: It means criticism or insults that have no effect on someone.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'be all ears' mean?
questions.answer: It means to listen very attentively with great interest.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'eager beaver' mean?
questions.answer: It means a person who is very enthusiastic and hard-working.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'barking up the wrong tree' mean?
questions.answer: It means pursuing the wrong course of action or looking in the wrong direction for a solution.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'get on your high horse' mean?
questions.answer: It means to behave in a superior or arrogant manner.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'Prevention is better than cure' mean?
questions.answer: It means it is easier to stop something bad from happening than to repair the damage after it has occurred.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'A stitch in time saves nine' mean?
questions.answer: It means fixing a small problem now prevents it from becoming a bigger problem later.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'The early bird catches the worm' mean?
questions.answer: It means those who act quickly or arrive first have the best chance of success.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'Birds of a feather flock together' mean?
questions.answer: It means people with similar interests, tastes, or characteristics tend to associate with each other.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'A friend in need is a friend indeed' mean?
questions.answer: It means a true friend is one who helps you when you are in trouble.
key_points: true friends help in difficult times

questions.question: Use the idiom 'on cloud nine' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Ravi was on cloud nine when he heard that he had topped the class examination.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'let the cat out of the bag' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Priya accidentally let the cat out of the bag about the surprise birthday party.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'take the bull by the horns' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Instead of avoiding the problem, she decided to take the bull by the horns and speak to her teacher directly.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'face the music' in a sentence.
questions.answer: After breaking the window, the boy had to face the music when his parents came home.

questions.question: Use the proverb 'A stitch in time saves nine' in a context.
questions.answer: When Meera noticed a small tear in her school bag, she fixed it immediately. As they say, a stitch in time saves nine - if she had waited, the tear would have become much bigger.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Like a ___ in a china shop' (meaning: clumsy or careless)
questions.explanation: A bull in a china shop would break everything - this describes someone who is clumsy in delicate situations.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Like a bear with a sore ___' (meaning: very irritated)
questions.explanation: Someone who is very irritated and in a bad mood.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Keep your nose to the ___' (meaning: keep working hard)
questions.explanation: To continue working hard without taking a break.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Set the world on ___' (meaning: do something remarkable)
questions.explanation: To do something remarkable or extraordinary that gains a lot of attention.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'A red rag to a ___' (meaning: something that makes someone very angry)
questions.explanation: Something that provokes anger or annoyance.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Cut a long story ___' (meaning: be precise)
questions.explanation: To tell only the essential parts and get to the point.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Break every rule in the ___' (meaning: do something unacceptable)
questions.explanation: To do something completely against all the rules.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Laugh up your ___' (meaning: have a secret laugh)
questions.explanation: To be secretly amused, especially at someone else's misfortune.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'Change horses in ___' (meaning: make changes during an ongoing activity)
questions.explanation: To make major changes when already in the middle of something.

questions.question: Complete the idiom: 'On the ___' (meaning: recovering from illness)
questions.explanation: To be recovering from an illness or injury.

questions.question: Which proverb would you use when someone is afraid of fire after getting burned once?
questions.answer: A burnt child dreads the fire. This proverb applies because someone who has had a bad experience is naturally cautious about similar situations.
key_points: A burnt child dreads the fire

questions.question: Which proverb would you use when advising someone to act quickly to take advantage of an opportunity?
questions.answer: Make hay while the sun shines. This means one should take advantage of favorable conditions while they last.
key_points: Make hay while the sun shines

questions.question: Which proverb would you use when someone's hard work finally brings success?
questions.answer: Hard work always pays off. This proverb reminds us that dedicated effort eventually leads to rewards.

questions.question: Which proverb would you use when a small business grows into a large company?
questions.answer: Tall oaks from small acorns grow. This proverb means that great things can have small beginnings.
key_points: Tall oaks from small acorns grow

questions.question: Which proverb would you use when a friend helps you during difficult times?
questions.answer: A friend in need is a friend indeed. This proverb means a true friend is one who helps you when you are in trouble.
key_points: A friend in need is a friend indeed

questions.question: The darkest hour is just before the ___.
questions.explanation: This proverb means that things often seem worst just before they get better.

questions.question: A bad workman blames his ___.
questions.explanation: Someone who does poor work blames their equipment rather than their own lack of skill.

questions.question: A rising tide lifts all ___.
questions.explanation: When something good happens to one, it often benefits everyone in the group.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'like a bull in a china shop' mean?
questions.answer: It means to be very clumsy or careless, especially in a delicate situation where you might break or damage things.

questions.question: What does the idiom 'keep your nose to the grindstone' mean?
questions.answer: It means to continue working hard without taking a break.

questions.question: Complete: 'Barking up the wrong ___' (meaning: pursuing the wrong course)
questions.explanation: Doing something that won't get the results you want.

questions.question: Complete: 'Get on your high ___' (meaning: behave arrogantly)
questions.explanation: To behave in a superior or arrogant manner.

questions.question: Complete: 'Make a beeline ___' (meaning: go directly towards)
questions.explanation: To go straight towards something without deviation.

questions.question: Complete: 'Water off a duck's ___' (meaning: no effect)
questions.explanation: Criticism that has no effect on someone.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'hold the fort' in a sentence.
questions.answer: While the manager was on vacation, his assistant held the fort and managed all the daily operations.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'paddle one's own canoe' in a sentence.
questions.answer: After graduation, Rahul decided to paddle his own canoe and started his own business instead of joining the family firm.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'put the cart before the horse' in a sentence.
questions.answer: By buying furniture before finding a house, they were putting the cart before the horse.

questions.question: Use the idiom 'a dog in the manger' in a sentence.
questions.answer: He was acting like a dog in the manger - he didn't want the old bicycle but wouldn't let his brother use it either.
key_points: preventing others from using what you don't need

questions.question: Use the idiom 'water off a duck's back' in a sentence.
questions.answer: The criticism was like water off a duck's back to him - he simply didn't let negative comments affect him.

questions.question: Use the proverb 'Make hay while the sun shines' in a context.
questions.answer: The salesman decided to work extra hours during the festival season because, as the saying goes, you should make hay while the sun shines - the opportunity won't last forever.

questions.question: Complete: 'Be all ___' (meaning: listen very attentively)
questions.explanation: To listen very attentively with great interest.

questions.question: Complete: '___ beaver' (meaning: very enthusiastic person)
questions.explanation: A very enthusiastic and hard-working person.

questions.question: What does 'abide by' mean?
questions.answer: It means to follow or comply with rules, decisions, or agreements.

questions.question: What does 'abstain from' mean?
questions.answer: It means to keep away from or refrain from something, especially something harmful.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'agree with' and 'agree to'?
questions.answer: 'Agree with' means to have the same opinion as someone. 'Agree to' means to consent to a suggestion or proposal.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'compare to' and 'compare with'?
questions.answer: 'Compare to' is used to note similarities between different things. 'Compare with' is used to compare things of the same class or category.
key_points: compare to = similarities between different things

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'He is addicted ___ video games.'
questions.explanation: 'Addicted to' means obsessed with or having a dependency on something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'She is capable ___ handling this task.'
questions.explanation: 'Capable of' means having the ability to do something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'We must abide ___ the rules.'
questions.explanation: 'Abide by' means to follow or comply with rules.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'She is blind ___ his faults.'
questions.explanation: 'Blind to' means failing to notice or be aware of something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'He is bent ___ achieving success.'
questions.explanation: 'Bent on' means very determined to do something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'Beware ___ pickpockets.'
questions.explanation: 'Beware of' means to be cautious of something dangerous.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'The book consists ___ ten chapters.'
questions.explanation: 'Consist of' means to be made up of or composed of.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'She is content ___ her simple life.'
questions.explanation: 'Content with' means satisfied with something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'This differs ___ what I expected.'
questions.explanation: 'Differ from' means to be different from something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'She is engaged ___ social work.'
questions.explanation: 'Engaged in' means occupied or involved in an activity.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'He is engaged ___ my cousin.'
questions.explanation: 'Engaged to' means formally agreed to marry someone.

questions.question: Use 'accede to' in a sentence.
questions.answer: The principal finally acceded to the students' request for an extra holiday.

questions.question: Use 'abstain from' in a sentence.
questions.answer: The doctor advised him to abstain from eating oily food.

questions.question: Use 'approve of' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Her parents did not approve of her decision to drop out of college.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'I do not approve ___ his behavior.'
questions.explanation: 'Approve of' means to have a positive feeling towards something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'He was accompanied ___ his wife.'
questions.explanation: 'Accompanied by' means to go with someone.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'She is accustomed ___ working late.'
questions.explanation: 'Accustomed to' means used to something.

questions.question: Fill in with the correct preposition: 'Can you distinguish ___ the twins?'
questions.explanation: 'Distinguish between' means to tell the difference between two things.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'The darkest hour is just before the dawn' mean?
questions.answer: It means that things often seem worst just before they get better. When you are going through a very difficult time, better times may be just around the corner.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'A bad workman blames his tools' mean?
questions.answer: It means that someone who does poor work tends to blame their equipment or circumstances rather than acknowledging their own lack of skill.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'A rising tide lifts all boats' mean?
questions.answer: It means that when something good happens to one person or thing, it often benefits everyone in the group or community.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'Still waters run deep' mean?
questions.answer: It means that a quiet or calm person may have deep thoughts, strong emotions, or hidden talents that are not immediately obvious.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'Nothing ventured, nothing gained' mean?
questions.answer: It means that you cannot achieve anything worthwhile without taking some risks. If you don't try, you won't succeed.

questions.question: What does the proverb 'The proof of the pudding is in the eating' mean?
questions.answer: It means that the true value or quality of something can only be judged when it is put to use or tested in practice.

questions.question: Complete: 'A blessing in ___' (meaning: something good that seemed bad at first)
questions.explanation: A good thing that initially appeared to be bad.

questions.question: Complete: 'Beat around the ___' (meaning: avoid saying what you mean)
questions.explanation: To avoid getting to the point or speaking directly.

questions.question: Complete: 'Bite the ___' (meaning: endure something painful but inevitable)
questions.explanation: To face a difficult situation with courage.

questions.question: Complete: 'Break a ___' (meaning: good luck)
questions.explanation: A way to wish someone good luck, especially performers.

questions.question: Complete: 'Call it a ___' (meaning: stop working)
questions.explanation: To stop working and rest for the day.

questions.question: Complete: 'Cutting ___' (meaning: doing something poorly to save time or money)
questions.explanation: To do something in a cheaper or easier way that reduces quality.

questions.question: Complete: 'Get out of ___' (meaning: get out of control)
questions.explanation: When a situation becomes uncontrollable.

questions.question: Complete: 'Hang in ___' (meaning: don't give up)
questions.explanation: To persist despite difficulties.

questions.question: Complete: 'Hit the ___' (meaning: go to sleep)
questions.explanation: To go to bed.

questions.question: Complete: 'Miss the ___' (meaning: it's too late)
questions.explanation: To miss an opportunity.

questions.question: Complete: 'No pain, no ___' (meaning: you must work for what you want)
questions.explanation: Success requires effort and sometimes discomfort.

questions.question: Complete: 'Pull someone's ___' (meaning: joke with someone)
questions.explanation: To tease or joke with someone playfully.

questions.question: Complete: 'Speak of the ___' (meaning: the person we were talking about appeared)
questions.explanation: Said when someone you were just discussing arrives.

questions.question: Complete: 'That's the last ___' (meaning: my patience has run out)
questions.explanation: The final problem in a series that causes one to lose patience.

questions.question: Complete: 'Under the ___' (meaning: feeling sick)
questions.explanation: Feeling unwell or ill.

questions.question: Complete: 'It's raining cats and ___' (meaning: raining heavily)
questions.explanation: Very heavy rain.

questions.question: Complete: 'Kill two birds with one ___' (meaning: accomplish two things at once)
questions.explanation: To achieve two goals with a single action.

questions.question: Complete: 'Once in a blue ___' (meaning: very rarely)
questions.explanation: Something that happens very infrequently.

questions.question: Complete: 'Spill the ___' (meaning: reveal a secret)
questions.explanation: To accidentally or deliberately reveal a secret.

questions.question: Complete: 'The ball is in your ___' (meaning: it's your decision)
questions.explanation: It's now your turn to make a decision or take action.

questions.question: Complete: 'Costs an arm and a ___' (meaning: very expensive)
questions.explanation: Something that is extremely expensive.

questions.question: Complete: 'It's a piece of ___' (meaning: it's easy)
questions.explanation: Something that is very easy to do.

questions.question: Complete: 'On thin ___' (meaning: in a risky situation)
questions.explanation: In a precarious or dangerous position.

questions.question: Complete: 'Burn ___' (meaning: destroy relationships)
questions.explanation: To permanently damage a relationship or opportunity.

questions.question: Complete: 'Fit as a ___' (meaning: in good health)
questions.explanation: In excellent physical condition.

questions.question: Complete: 'Through thick and ___' (meaning: in good times and bad)
questions.explanation: Remaining loyal through all circumstances.

questions.question: Complete: 'Absence makes the heart grow ___' (meaning: being apart makes you appreciate more)
questions.explanation: Being away from someone makes you love them more.

questions.question: Complete: 'Actions speak louder than ___' (meaning: what you do matters more than what you say)
questions.explanation: Deeds are more important than promises.

questions.question: Complete: 'All good things must come to an ___' (meaning: nothing lasts forever)
questions.explanation: Good times eventually finish.

questions.question: Complete: 'Beggars can't be ___' (meaning: accept what you're given)
questions.explanation: Those in need cannot be picky about help offered.

questions.question: Complete: 'Don't bite the hand that ___ you' (meaning: don't hurt those helping you)
questions.explanation: Don't harm those who support you.

questions.question: Complete: 'Honesty is the best ___' (meaning: always tell the truth)
questions.explanation: Being truthful is always the best approach.

questions.question: Complete: 'Knowledge is ___' (meaning: the more you know, the stronger you are)
questions.explanation: Information and learning give you advantages.

questions.question: Complete: 'Practice makes ___' (meaning: repetition leads to mastery)
questions.explanation: Consistent practice improves your skills.

questions.question: Complete: 'Two heads are better than ___' (meaning: working together is easier)
questions.explanation: Collaboration produces better results.

questions.question: Complete: 'Two wrongs don't make a ___' (meaning: revenge doesn't fix things)
questions.explanation: Responding to wrongdoing with wrongdoing doesn't help.

questions.question: Complete: 'Time is ___' (meaning: don't waste time)
questions.explanation: Time is valuable and should not be wasted.

questions.question: Complete: 'The pen is mightier than the ___' (meaning: words are more powerful than violence)
questions.explanation: Ideas and communication are more effective than force.

questions.question: Complete: 'The grass is always greener on the other ___' (meaning: others' situations seem better)
questions.explanation: We tend to think others have it better than us.

questions.question: Complete: 'Where there's smoke, there's ___' (meaning: signs of problems indicate real problems)
questions.explanation: If there are signs of a problem, a problem probably exists.

questions.question: What does 'a blessing in disguise' mean?
questions.answer: It means something that initially seems bad but turns out to be good.

questions.question: What does 'beat around the bush' mean?
questions.answer: It means to avoid speaking directly about something, usually because it's uncomfortable.

questions.question: What does 'bite the bullet' mean?
questions.answer: It means to endure a painful or difficult situation because it cannot be avoided.

questions.question: What does 'call it a day' mean?
questions.answer: It means to stop working on something and rest.

questions.question: What does 'cutting corners' mean?
questions.answer: It means doing something poorly or cheaply to save time or money.

questions.question: What does 'speak of the devil' mean?
questions.answer: It's said when someone you were just talking about suddenly appears.

questions.question: What does 'under the weather' mean?
questions.answer: It means feeling sick or unwell.

questions.question: What does 'it's raining cats and dogs' mean?
questions.answer: It means it's raining very heavily.

questions.question: What does 'kill two birds with one stone' mean?
questions.answer: It means to accomplish two things with a single action.

questions.question: What does 'once in a blue moon' mean?
questions.answer: It means very rarely or almost never.

questions.question: What does 'spill the beans' mean?
questions.answer: It means to reveal a secret, usually accidentally.

questions.question: What does 'costs an arm and a leg' mean?
questions.answer: It means something is very expensive.

questions.question: What does 'on thin ice' mean?
questions.answer: It means being in a risky or dangerous situation where you might get in trouble.

questions.question: What does 'burn bridges' mean?
questions.answer: It means to permanently damage relationships or destroy opportunities.

questions.question: What does 'absence makes the heart grow fonder' mean?
questions.answer: It means being away from someone or something makes you appreciate them more.

questions.question: What does 'actions speak louder than words' mean?
questions.answer: It means what you do is more important than what you say.

questions.question: What does 'beggars can't be choosers' mean?
questions.answer: It means if you need help, you should accept what's offered without being picky.

questions.question: What does 'don't bite the hand that feeds you' mean?
questions.answer: It means don't hurt or criticize someone who helps you.

questions.question: What does 'honesty is the best policy' mean?
questions.answer: It means it's always better to tell the truth than to lie.

questions.question: What does 'practice makes perfect' mean?
questions.answer: It means the more you practice something, the better you become at it.

questions.question: Use 'a blessing in disguise' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Losing my job was a blessing in disguise because I found a much better one.

questions.question: Use 'beat around the bush' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Stop beating around the bush and tell me what really happened.

questions.question: Use 'under the weather' in a sentence.
questions.answer: I'm feeling a bit under the weather today, so I'll stay home and rest.

questions.question: Use 'kill two birds with one stone' in a sentence.
questions.answer: By walking to school, I kill two birds with one stone - I get exercise and save money on transport.

questions.question: Use 'it's raining cats and dogs' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Take an umbrella - it's raining cats and dogs outside!

questions.question: Use 'actions speak louder than words' in a sentence.
questions.answer: He keeps promising to help, but actions speak louder than words - I want to see him actually do something.

questions.question: Use 'practice makes perfect' in a sentence.
questions.answer: Don't give up on learning the guitar. Practice makes perfect!

questions.question: Use 'honesty is the best policy' in a sentence.
questions.answer: I decided to tell my parents the truth because honesty is the best policy.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'being away from someone makes you value them more'?
questions.answer: Absence makes the heart grow fonder.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'what you do is more important than what you say'?
Which proverb means 'the more you know, the more capable you become'?
Which proverb means 'people always want what they don't have'?
questions.answer: The grass is always greener on the other side.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'working together is more effective than alone'?
questions.answer: Two heads are better than one.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'if there are signs of a problem, there probably is one'?
Which idiom means 'something that is very easy to do'?
Which idiom means 'to go to bed'?
questions.answer: Hit the sack (or hit the hay).

questions.question: Which idiom means 'the person we were talking about just arrived'?
Which idiom means 'very rarely'?
Which idiom means 'feeling sick or unwell'?
Which idiom means 'my patience has run out'?
